questionList.title: Scaphoid fracture
questionList.topicAttribute: Bone, joint, and soft tissue injuries and infections

answerChoiceList.choice: Thumb spica splint and repeat radiography in 10 days

questionList.questionText: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with low back and left hip pain.  The patient tripped at work and fell backwards, landing on his left side.  He has no head injury or loss of consciousness.  Medical history is unremarkable.  Blood pressure is 148/90 mm Hg, pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 18/min.  On examination, the left paraspinal lumbar area and left hip are tender to palpation.  The neurovascular examination is intact.  X-ray is obtained and is shown in the exhibit.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Femoral neck fracture

Clinical presentation

  • Severe hip pain & inability to bear weight after a fall
  • Risk factors: age >65, frailty, osteoporosis

Examination findings

  • Shortened, externally rotated leg
  • Painful range of motion
  • Ecchymosis

X-ray findings

  • Disruption of cortical contour
  • External rotation of distal fragment (prominence of lesser trochanter profile)
  • Shortening of neck
  • Lucency or hazy sclerosis at fracture plane

Management

  • Open reduction/internal fixation or arthroplasty

This patient's x-ray reveals common features of a femoral neck fracture, including shortening of the neck, disruption of the normal cortical contour, and irregular lucency at the fracture plane.  Femoral neck fractures are most common at age >65, typically presenting with hip pain after a fall.  Displaced fractures may show shortening and external rotation of the affected extremity due to unopposed contraction of the iliopsoas and gluteus medius, but this finding is not always readily visible.

The femoral neck has a thin periosteum and a tenuous blood supply that can be disrupted by injury; femoral neck fractures have a significant risk of complications, including secondary instability, avascular necrosis, malunion, and degenerative changes in the femoral head.  Therefore, surgical repair with either open reduction/internal fixation or (hemi)arthroplasty is indicated for most patients.

(Choices A, D, and E)  Most stable pelvic fractures are managed with pain control and early mobilization (eg, weight bearing as tolerated).  Also, pubic rami fractures often can be managed nonoperatively with pain control and physical therapy.  Sacral insufficiency fractures are often treated initially with pain control and non–weight bearing.  Although nonoperative management is often recommended for nonambulatory, debilitated patients with femoral neck fracture, ambulatory patients require surgical repair.

(Choice C)  CT scan of the pelvis is not usually needed if fracture is confirmed on x-ray.  In the case of a normal x-ray but high suspicion for fracture (eg, inability to bear weight), CT scan can be obtained.

Educational objective:
Femoral neck fractures are most common in elderly individuals, typically presenting with hip pain after a fall.  Common x-ray findings include shortening of the femoral neck, disruption of the normal cortical contour, and irregular lucency at the fracture plane.  Femoral neck fractures have a significant risk of complications (eg, secondary instability, malunion), and surgical repair is indicated for most patients.
questionList.subject: Surgery
questionList.title: Hip fracture
questionList.topicAttribute: Bone, joint, and soft tissue injuries and infections

answerChoiceList.choice: Admit for nonoperative pain control and physical therapy
CT scan of the pelvis without contrast
Discharge with crutches and instructions for weight bearing as tolerated
Discharge with non–weight-bearing instructions and outpatient physical therapy

questionList.questionText: A 52-year-old man comes to the clinic for follow-up of a nonhealing wound on his right leg.  Eight months ago, the patient had an open fracture of his right tibia due to a motorcycle accident.  His injury was surgically treated, and for 2 weeks afterward he had occasional fevers that resolved with a course of antibiotics.  For the past month, he has had clear drainage from the wound, which has required daily changing of the dressing.  The patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus, which is treated with insulin, and hypertension.  On examination, there is a chronic wound, and the overlying dressing contains a scant amount of serosanguinous fluid.  There is pain at the fracture site and the patient is unable to bear full weight on the leg.  Dorsiflexion of the ankle causes minimal discomfort.  Pedal pulses are palpable.  X-ray of the leg is shown in the exhibit.  Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Chronic osteomyelitis

Mechanisms

  • Hematogenous seeding
  • Extension from infection in adjacent structure
  • Direct inoculation (eg, compound fracture, bite wound)

Pathogens

  • Staphylococcus aureus (most common)
  • Coagulase-negative staphylococci
  • Polymicrobial

Risk factors

  • Surgical hardware/instrumentation
  • Diabetes
  • Impaired circulation or sensation in the limb

Clinical features

  • Persistent pain, swelling, chronic wound
  • Sinus tract formation
  • Nonunion of fracture

Diagnosis

  • Positive probe-to-bone test
  • Imaging: lytic lesion with loss of cortical & trabecular bone, surrounding sclerosis, periosteal thickening
  • Bone biopsy for culture

Management

  • Surgical debridement
  • Antibiotics (prolonged course)

This patient has a tibial fracture complicated by nonunion, defined as failure of a fracture to achieve radiographic or clinical evidence of union within an adequate time frame (eg, 6 months for long bone shaft fractures).  Risk factors for nonunion include impaired blood flow (eg, smoking, arterial atherosclerosis), certain medications (eg, systemic glucocorticoids), metabolic disorders (eg, diabetes, hypothyroidism), and infection (eg, osteomyelitis).

Acute osteomyelitis typically presents with local pain, erythema, and fever over a few days or weeks.  However, if the bony infection is not completely eradicated, it can lead to a chronic, indolent infection (ie, chronic osteomyelitis) with necrosis and fragmentation (sequestrum) of the bone.  Chronic osteomyelitis is a common complication of high-velocity tibial fractures because the bony fragments are often exposed and the blood supply may be disrupted by trauma.

A sinus tract with a persistently draining wound, as in this patient, strongly suggests chronic osteomyelitis.  Intermittent pain and swelling may occur; however, fever and leukocytosis are usually less prominent.  The diagnosis is suggested by this patient's x-ray, which shows fragmentation of the bone and ragged, irregular fracture lines.  Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein are often elevated.  Open bone biopsy is preferred over percutaneous aspiration for microbiologic sampling; culture of sinus tracts generally has poor sensitivity and specificity.  Surgical debridement of the infected and necrotic bone is required for definitive management.

(Choice A)  Amputation is often required for diabetic patients with ulcers that do not heal due to impaired blood flow.  However, this patient's sinus tract is caused by chronic osteomyelitis, and aggressive treatment of the infection may allow limb salvage.

(Choice B)  A CT angiogram to assess vascular status is indicated for patients with fractures associated with absent distal pulses.  Although violent fractures can cause disruption of the tibial blood flow despite palpable distal pulses, other vascular signs (eg, pallor or mottling of the skin, decreased sensation) are usually present.

(Choice C)  Surgical fixation with insertion of additional hardware without first eliminating the infection would likely result in infection of the hardware.  Once the infection is fully eradicated, additional orthopedic fixation could be considered.

(Choices D and E)  Silver sulfadiazine and skin grafting are often used for burn wounds.  These superficial interventions would not treat the deep infection.

Educational objective:
Chronic osteomyelitis may lead to fracture nonunion.  Common symptoms include intermittent pain and swelling and sinus tract formation.  Open bone biopsy is recommended for microbiologic assessment, and treatment requires surgical debridement of the infected and necrotic bone.
questionList.subject: Surgery
questionList.title: Osteomyelitis
questionList.topicAttribute: Bone, joint, and soft tissue injuries and infections

answerChoiceList.choice: Immediate surgical fixation of the tibia
Silver sulfadiazine cream and sterile dressing application
Split-thickness skin graft to the soft tissue defect

questionList.questionText:
A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after his daughter found him on the floor.  The patient says that he fell just prior to his daughter's arrival and now his left hip "hurts a lot," but he does not recall any details of the fall and is uncertain whether he lost consciousness.  Over the past several days, he has felt short of breath with a cough and intermittent palpitations that he attributed to "coming down with the flu."  He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and benign prostatic hyperplasia.  Temperature is 37.3 C (99.1 F), blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg, pulse is 116/min, and respirations are 24/min.  Pulse oximetry shows 95% on 2 L/min of oxygen by nasal cannula.  The patient is alert and oriented with no signs of head injury.  Breath sounds are decreased at the right lung base, and crackles are present at the left lung base.  The left lower extremity is shortened and externally rotated.  Initial laboratory studies, including complete blood count, glucose, serum chemistries, and coagulation panel, are normal.  X-ray of the pelvis is shown below.

Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient experienced an unwitnessed fall resulting in a left femoral neck fracture.  Most hip fractures require surgical fixation; the specific intervention required (eg, total hip arthroplasty, intramedullary nail) depends on the exact location and details of the individual case.  In medically stable patients, surgical repair should be performed as soon as feasible (typically within 24 hr) to relieve pain, minimize complications, and reduce the length of hospital stay.  However, in patients with unstable medical conditions, such as this one, surgery may be temporarily delayed to perform a more extensive preoperative evaluation.

This patient's inability to recall the circumstances of his fall and his uncertainty about whether he lost consciousness raise suspicion for a syncopal episode.  His tachycardia and palpitations may be due to arrhythmia.  Decreased breath sounds on the right side could be due to pleural effusion; cough, dyspnea, and left basilar crackles also suggest pulmonary edema or pneumonia.  The patient should therefore be evaluated with electrocardiography, cardiac markers, and chest x-ray (and likely echocardiography) to determine the etiology of his fall and assess his preoperative risk prior to surgical correction of his fracture (eg, acute decompensated heart failure and unstable arrhythmia are considered high-risk features warranting further workup) (Choice B).  Once his medical condition is diagnosed and optimized (eg, diuresis for heart failure), he may be cleared for surgical intervention.  A delay of surgery of >72 hours should be avoided when possible because this has been associated with increased morbidity (Choice E).

(Choice C)  Intravenous crystalloid boluses may be indicated in patients with hypovolemia (eg, causing orthostatic syncope).  However, this patient has evidence of possible volume overload (eg, decreased breath sounds, pulmonary crackles) rather than hypovolemia, making intravenous crystalloid boluses potentially detrimental.  Pulmonary edema (eg, from heart failure) and pleural effusion should be ruled out first with chest x-ray.

(Choice D)  Skeletal traction has been advocated as an interim measure for patients with hip fracture who require delayed surgical repair.  However, recent studies have found that traction does not relieve pain or improve surgical outcomes.  In addition, it is only a temporary measure and is not used for fracture healing.

Educational objective:
Most hip fractures require surgical fixation, which should be performed early (typically within 24 hr) in medically stable patients to relieve pain, minimize complications, and reduce the length of hospital stay.  However, in patients with unstable medical conditions (eg, syncope, heart failure), surgery may be delayed up to 72 hours to evaluate surgical risk and optimize medical stability.

answerChoiceList.choice: Electrocardiography, cardiac markers, and chest x-ray
Immediate surgical repair for femoral neck fracture
Lower-extremity skeletal traction for fracture healing

questionList.questionText:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to refusal to walk.  The patient's mother first noticed a mild limp 3 days ago after picking him up from day care.  The patient tends to climb and jump on furniture, so she initially attributed the limp to rough play.  The symptoms worsened today, and the patient now refuses to stand, falling when held up by his mother.  He has no chronic medical conditions but has had a runny nose and fever intermittently for 2 months since starting day care.  Temperature is 38 C (100.4 F), pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 24/min.  Pulse oximetry is 100% on room air.  The patient appears comfortable while lying supine on the examination table.  He has clear rhinorrhea with several soft and mobile anterior cervical lymph nodes approximately 1 cm in diameter.  The abdomen is nontender and the liver edge is palpable.  The hips are held flexed bilaterally.  During movement of the left hip, the patient wails and resists.  Sensation is normal, and reflexes are intact.  Babinski sign is negative bilaterally.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
    Hemoglobin11.5 g/dL
    Platelets380,000/mm3
    Leukocytes15,000/mm3
        Neutrophils80%
        Lymphocytes20%
Immunologic and rheumatologic studies
    Erythrocyte sedimentation rate30 mm/hr

Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Transient synovitis vs septic arthritis

Transient synovitis

Septic arthritis

Clinical
presentation

  • Well-appearing
  • Afebrile or low-grade fever
  • Able to bear weight
  • Ill-appearing
  • Febrile
  • Non–weight-bearing

Diagnosis

  • Normal or mildly elevated WBCs, ESR, CRP
  • Unilateral/bilateral joint effusion on ultrasonography
  • Diagnosis of exclusion
  • Moderately elevated WBCs, ESR, CRP
  • ± Positive blood culture
  • Unilateral joint effusion on ultrasonography
  • Synovial fluid WBCs >50,000/mm3

Treatment

  • Conservative
  • Joint drainage & antibiotics

CRP = C-reactive protein; ESR = erythrocyte sedimentation rate; WBCs = white blood cells.

The most common cause of atraumatic hip pain and limp in children is transient synovitis, a self-limiting, inflammatory condition often preceded by a viral illness.  However, transient synovitis must be distinguished from septic arthritis, a potentially life-threatening infection requiring emergency treatment (eg, intravenous antibiotics).

Clinical features help distinguish between the 2 conditions:

  • Transient synovitis typically presents in children age 3-8 who are afebrile or have a low-grade fever.  Patients have pain and limited mobility of the affected joint but can usually bear weight.  Leukocyte count and inflammatory markers (eg, erythrocyte sedimentation rate [ESR], C-reactive protein [CRP]) are normal or slightly elevated.

  • In contrast, septic arthritis findings include high fever, inability to ambulate (severe pain), and abnormal laboratory evaluation (eg, leukocytosis, elevated ESR/CRP).

Sometimes patients can have overlapping clinical features, as in this child with a low-grade fever and mildly elevated ESR (suggestive of transient synovitis) but with severe pain, inability to ambulate, and leukocytosis with neutrophil predominance (suggestive of septic arthritis).

When the diagnosis is unclear, bilateral hip ultrasound is performed.  Joint effusion in septic arthritis is unilateral, whereas 25% of patients with transient synovitis have bilateral hip effusions (even with unilateral symptoms).  If hip ultrasound shows a unilateral effusion, arthrocentesis is required to evaluate for septic arthritis.

(Choice B)  CT scan can identify a psoas abscess, which presents with fever and abdominal pain that may radiate to the hip.  This patient's nontender abdomen makes psoas abscess unlikely.  In addition, for initial evaluation of the hip, ultrasound is preferred over CT because it can detect and characterize a joint effusion while avoiding radiation exposure.

(Choice C)  Ibuprofen and close follow-up are the management of transient synovitis.  However, this patient's inability to ambulate requires further evaluation.

(Choice D)  Lumbar puncture is indicated for suspected Guillain-Barré syndrome, which may present with refusal to walk (due to weakness) and neuropathic pain.  This patient's normal strength and reflexes make this diagnosis unlikely.

(Choice E)  Lymph node biopsy may be performed for suspected leukemia, which can present with fever and bone pain.  However, generalized lymphadenopathy or hematologic abnormalities would be expected.

Educational objective:
Acute, atraumatic hip pain in children is typically caused by transient synovitis, which presents in well-appearing children who are often afebrile and able to ambulate.  However, patients with features concerning for septic arthritis (eg, inability to ambulate, leukocytosis) require bilateral hip ultrasound, with or without arthrocentesis, to distinguish between the conditions.
